q: Why do some flood barriers leak at the base?
a: Base leaks usually stem from uneven thresholds or insufficient gasket compression. We correct these by laser-leveling the track and adjusting torque on compression bolts to 35–40 ft-lb.

q: How do you fix barriers that won't seat properly?
a: Check for debris in the bottom track, verify panel orientation, and inspect for aluminum expansion in high heat. We recommend a 1⁄16-inch thermal allowance on panels wider than 60 inches.

q: Why does my barrier bow during heavy rain?
a: Bowing indicates unequal pressure or blocked scupper drains. Ensure drain holes remain clear and panels are evenly torqued.

q: How often should gaskets be replaced?
a: Every 5 years in coastal environments, 7–8 years inland. Degraded gaskets cause seepage even when panels appear tight.

q: Can barriers fail from water pressure?
a: Only if improperly anchored or overtopped. All systems are pressure-tested beyond expected static loads before shipment.

q: What to do if hardware rusts?
a: Replace corroded bolts with 316 stainless. Apply anti-seize compound annually to prevent galling.

q: Can existing leaks be repaired without full replacement?
a: Yes. We reseal with EPDM inserts and reset anchors without removing entire frames, restoring full hydrostatic rating.
